Award.AwardTitle: ARTS: A cyber-enabled global monograph of Viburnum (Adoxaceae, Dipsacales)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The genus Viburnum contains some 170 woody plant species in temperate and subtropical forests around the Northern Hemisphere and in Latin America and Southeast Asia. Over 70 Viburnum species are used in horticulture, and many are ecologically important. Building on years of prior research, and based directly upon herbarium specimens and new collections, the goal of this project is to resolve all remaining species-level taxonomic problems and to produce a comprehensive description of the entire group, with geographic range maps and richly-illustrated interactive identification keys that can be deployed on the web and in the field. All data will be internet-accessible and integrated into global biodiversity databases.

This project will produce a global treatment of a widespread, taxonomically confusing, and horticulturally important plant lineage. In doing so, it will generate data and informatics tools of general value to the scientific community. This work will greatly increase the value of Viburnum as a model for addressing fundamental issues in evolutionary biology, ecology, and global change. The project will be transformative in modeling the use of knowledge of evolutionary relationships in producing a species-level taxonomic monograph. It will provide hands-on training in modern, collaborative, cyber-enabled systematic biology to students at all levels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

Viburnum is a diverse group of woody flowering plants that is widely distributed around the Northern Hemisphere and widely cultivated.  Viburnum taxonomy has been highly confusing owing to complex patterns of morphological variation in nature and the rapid diversification of lineages in certain regions.  Some 1,380 scientific names have been applied in the literature to Viburnum species and subspecific taxa.  However, based on the analyses supported by this award, we now recognize a total of 164 species.  Eastern Asia is the center of diversity, with 102 species representing 14 major lineages.  There are seven species in Europe representing four lineages, and 19 species in North America (north of Mexico) belonging to six separate lineages.  In the neo-tropics there are 36 species in three lineages, but with 34 of these belonging to just a single lineage.  Our analyses infer an Asian origin for Viburnum dating back at least to the Paleocene, with four movements to Europe, six to North America (two older and four younger, all presumably through the Bering Land Bridge), and the radiation of one ancestrally North American lineage into the mountains of Mexico and Central America, and then into the Andes of South America.  

We have included 155 of the 164 species in molecular phylogenetic analyses, almost entirely based on plants collected by the PIs in the wild.  All of these collections have been critically identified and properly vouchered with herbarium specimens.  Our molecular analyses are based on whole chloroplast genome sequences for 22 species, and a ten-gene dataset including nine chloroplast genes and nuclear ribosomal Internal Transcribed Spacer (ITS) sequences.  Recently, 110 species have been included in a RAD (Restriction-Site Associated DNA) sequencing analysis, which yielded variation (Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms) in as many as 60,000 genetic loci.  Our chloroplast and nuclear datasets support almost identical relationships among the major clades.  Support for relationships within the rapidly diversifying lineages is generally poor using only chloroplast markers, but strong in RAD-Seq analyses.  Together these studies provide an exceptionally complete and confidently resolved phylogenetic framework within which we have conducted detailed taxonomic studies focused on the delimitation of species within pairs (or small sets) of closely related populations.  The objective has been to identify lineages that appear to be evolving independently of one another, taking into account morphological and geographic differences.  In several of the most complicated cases (e.g., the V. dentatum species complex in eastern North America), molecular data have supported more detailed phylogeographic analyses.     

Critical to the success of the project were 14 collecting expeditions supported in part by this award.  Over the four years covered by the grant, multiple specimens have been made of ~350 Viburnum individuals, representing more than three quarters of the extant Viburnum species.  This includes a number of rare but phylogenetically critical species from tropical forests in Southeast Asia.  In addition, we visited 29 herbaria to annotate and digitize Viburnum specimens.  Together, these data supported the production of authoritative geographic range maps and ecological niche models for almost all of the currently recognized species. 

NSF funding for the production of a world-wide cyber-monograph of Viburnum supported the preparation of 18 published papers that acknowledged the award.   In addition, the results of this project were disseminated through 20 departmental seminars by the Principal Investigators, seven plenary or keynote addresses, and 17 contributed talks or posters at national scientific meetings.  Most importantly, we designed and populated Virtual Viburnum, an interactive web-based repository of data and images on all species of Viburnum.  Currently, this serves records of 7,872 specimens of Viburnum from 30 herbaria, and 6,843 digital images of herbarium specimens, of plants in the field, of collecting localities, and a variety of key characteristics (e.g., trichomes, pollen grains, leaf venation).  Three postdoctoral students, four graduate students, and 14 undergraduate students were funded in part through this award, and obtained training in various aspects of systematic biology.

Our studies have resulted in the creation of a comprehensive new classification of Viburnum, in which names for all of the major lineages have been given formal definitions (Clement et al., 2014).  Using this new framework, the PIs and their collaborators conducted detailed analyses of a variety of traits, including extrafloral nectaries, leaf shape and margins, leaf packing within winter buds, leaf anatomy in relation to photosynthetic capacity, leaf life span and branching architecture, leaf hydraulic architecture, and wood anatomy.  Other studies have focused on the morphological traits that differentiate the major lineages (e.g., inflorescence type, pollen characteristics, trichomes, and endosperm), and on patterns of speciation and extinction in relation to the occupation of different forest types.  Collectively, these studies demonstrate the power of a deep understanding of the systematics of a group of organisms and the value of developing model lineages for studies of ecology and evolutionary biology.
